summary: This document is a chain of emails from September 2019 discussing the status of the 'taint review' of materials seized from Jeffrey Epstein's Manhattan residence. Prosecutors and law enforcement are coordinating to review electronic evidence, noting a surprisingly low volume of documents (about 20,000 files) and discussing procedures with Epstein's defense attorneys.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the investigation; materials were seized from his Manhattan residence.

events.title: Materials from Epstein's residence made available
events.description: Materials seized from Jeffrey Epstein's Manhattan residence were made available for review.

events.title: Email discussion on taint review status
events.description: Prosecutors and law enforcement exchange emails about the progress and volume of the taint review of seized materials.

keyFacts: A taint review was being conducted on materials seized from Jeffrey Epstein's Manhattan residence, which were made available on September 10, 2019.
The volume of documents from approximately 20 devices and hard drives was noted to be surprisingly low, at about 20,000 files, with many being non-user files like Adobe instructions.
Epstein's attorney had provided search terms for the taint review, and there was discussion about whether to release materials to the defense or give them notice first.
Law enforcement supervisors were requesting status updates for a meeting with the ADIC (Assistant Director in Charge) about the case.
